name: Puzzle Quest: Galactrix
description: The puzzle game of the future has arrived! The original best-selling new Puzzle franchise is back in an all new dimension with its signature Match-3, turn based battles in an insanely addictive and masterful hybrid of RPG and Puzzle genres.

reviews.review_text: For 99cents you can not go wrong with this game. I have played for 3 hours already today. I know I will play a lot more. 99 cents for all that time playing. And it's fun. It is hard to wrap your head around the unique angles that the swaping takes place on, but that is part of the charm of these games.

Very casual game, with slight RPG elements, and a simple but enjoyable storyline. If you like games that you can play with one hand on the mouse, and the other hand on your beer, buy it. It's cheap fun.
Good mix of space mining/trading game and match 3+ puzzle game.

I can't help, but notice insane amount of negative reviews, bashing the game for all sorts of gameplay issues, i.e. constant crashes, unfair AI etc.  I played the game for couple of hours offline, so don't pay attention to time record, and I didn't experience a single crash (played on Win7 64bit, CPU: AMD, GPU: NVIDIA) I should try to play online a bit, if crashes occur - I'll update my comment. My only real complaint for current is the lack of controller support of any sorts.  Also I haven't find AI cheating at all. I admit, the enemy pretty much owned me at first, but, understandably, I accepted all my failures, because the board layout completely differs from original PQ series, so it takes time to learn the predictable patterns for falling tiles (truly, as the story take place in zero-gravity space, new tiles can be falling from all directions, not just from up-to-down) So, once you figure out how the board works - the enemies would become no problem. And learning new puzzle mechanics is always fair and interesting challenge.  Speaking of the space setting: that's another thing you can easily praise 'PQ: Galactrix' for. They have successfully managed to rework the whole mechanics of the original game and blend in the usual space fiction tropes with new gameplay features (say, for example, aforementioned zero-gravity battle grid with tiles falling from all directions or the mandatory for space games mining business, that was combined here with useful weapon crafting or selling the extracted minerals to the star systems, willing to pay the best price per ton.. Or selling the cargo cheaply to a hostile race to buy their loyalty)  The game atmosphere has heavily reminded me in many ways of 'Space Rangers' - another game series I love very much. Surely, Galactrix is a nice spin-off and worth at least the summer sale price, which is what I bought it for and thoroughly enjoyed playing the game - I'd say, give it a shot.

I find myself laughing at the sheer torrent of negative reviews I've found for this game, both here and everywhere else all over the Internet. Most of those can be written off as either 'I don't know how to play, so it's a bad game' or 'Nothing like the first Puzzle Quest game, so I don't like it'. People who write reviews with those sentiments as their core points should not be allowed to write reviews.  The puzzle board is a refreshing change to the standard 'match 3+ of a color' formula. Six directions allows for so many possibilities to surprise an enemy with a strange combo.  Combat is well-crafted and challenging, and there is always a way to win if you're willing to look for it, whether through a suddenly-favorable board configuration or a way to exploit the enemy's resources so they can't use their items while maximizing use of your own.  Hacking LeapGates does not deserve the massive level of criticism I've seen it get; it's a straightforward puzzle, with a simple goal. Yes, you have to hack every gate you want to pass through, but since people seem to think this is tedious, there's always an option to use your PSI points to open the gate automatically - and you're never going to run out of those unless you're reckless, or you use them to dodge every battle.  Haggling for discounts is small and motivating; you always want to do well. It's a minor annoyance that you have to do it for each item you want to buy or sell, but it only makes a real difference for the more expensive purchases like ships, so it's not a concern for the smaller items.  Rumor puzzles are well-designed, but serve little purpose other than as collectibles and experience. I do wish they would've played a larger role, because the puzzles are better than what they're used for.  The faction system is expansive and logical. If you make someone hate you, they'll make sure you don't pass through their worlds without a fight. I see little basis for the near-universal criticism of the game's characters, since the situation the universe is in pretty much justifies the near-total pessimism. And the fun part: it's entirely possible to become allies with literally every faction, except for the story's main antagonist - even the pirates.  I'd never heard of the Puzzle Quest series when I found this game. I'm a huge fan of puzzle games overall, and the RPG elements are a very welcome bonus. The negative reviews actually helped convince me to buy it, since it just seemed absurd that people would hate the game for things that have nothing to do with the actual gameplay. I did get it on a 90% sale, but that doesn't change anything. Galactrix is a beautiful, well-designed game.

In Galactrix Conquest, you battle your enemy one puzzle at a time for total control of the galaxy. Every planet has two battle fields. You must attain victory on both puzzle fields to control the planet. The winner of each puzzle chooses where to attack next. Each world that you control grants your faction a planetary bonus that can be used to enhance your forces, or to sabatoge your enemy. For example, if the Empire controls the planet Tatooine, Lord Vader will assist Imperial Troops by crushing Rebel opposition during puzzles. With each victory your faction's dominance increases. After four victories your faction will be powerful enough to use the special bonus granted by your secret base. 'Choose a planet to destroy.' The Empire can use their secret base to unleashe the awesome power of the Death Star and obliterate a Rebel planet completely.
candy crush without the transactions  10/10 BUY NOW.

Think of it like a basic GEMS puzzle game, only the rules change slightly depending on the situation. The board shape may change, the direction they drop may change, and so on.  Further, depending on how your 'ship' is outfitted, you will be trying to match different gems. For example, you may need to do 100 damage to an enemy to win, and your rockets deal 1 damage Per red gem on the board - but you also need to have removed atleast 10 to use it. Coupled that the AI will have their own strategy, and the game is turn based, makes for interesting gameplay.  You dip in and out and have great fun with it - just DO NOT expect much from the 'rpg' or 'story' elements. Those suck.

I really enjoy this, even if it dose have its issues. Bad points, ill agree with other people and say the puzzles and enemy A.I. does feel a bit cheety and the tutorial could be better, however, the good bits are that for a puzzl game it is rather fun, yet simple. I found myself confused at fisrt, but qickly worked out how the game works. If you manage to catch this on sale (£3 or less) then i would reccomend it, otherwise its up to you.

Never had the crashing error but it seems to be prevalent based on other reviews. Maybe I'll go back and play it all the way through one day if I'm feeling ambitious.  3/10 Would not recommend

Awful tagalong sequel to a game that, despite its' many faults, remained enjoyable. The new three-direction mechanics add nothing to the game except hassle, the ship/item setup is immensely unrewarding, and the cheating AI is now so transparent it's actually embarassing. If you enjoyed PQ, avoid Galactrix. In fact, just avoid; you can do so much better elsewhere.

I bought this game on sale for $0.99 and I overpaid. They kept all the bad AI problems from the original Puzzle Quest (overpowered early enemy skills, miraculous drop-in combos for AI opponents, etc.) and heaped on top of that a flat, shallow story and too many uninteresting, cumbersome, or flat out tedious new features.

After playing close to 200 hours of the first Puzzle Quest, i thought 'hey, this one's also on sale, may as well buy it'.  lets cut to the chase: game is literally unplayable.  the game freezes a lot, crashed on me 3 times, and the interface blows.  this looks like it was sloppily put together, and there is really nothing nice i can say about it.  the artwork is bad, the game mechanics, where in the first game acted similiar to bejewled, this one keeps the 'straight line' function, but makes the game board a circle.  WHY. WHO SAID THIS WAS A GOOD IDEA. You will miss many turns (assuming the game loads) because it's disorienting and is very hard to get used to when your game keeps freezing.  DO. NOT. BUY.  I spent .99c on it, and i feel bad giving them any amount of money.  the first one is much better and is worth the $

I can't recommend this.  The game has four different types of puzzles to my knowledge. I didn't get too far into it. They all play the same way, you group three, pieces slide around, you group another three until you finish. The first type is the 'battle' puzzles where you and an opponent take turns either grouping three or using a weapon but the random nature takes a lot of the fun out of these. I did pretty well with only a couple retrys but when I won, it was completely random. I would group three bombs, the pieces would slide into a combo, more bombs would appear on the board, they would slide into a combo, and I would win. No skill here, just randomness. Oh, and making a wrong move (IE: Moving pieces that don't make a group of three) results in taking ship damage. So you're punished for making mistakes.  Then there are the hacking puzzles. These are extremely tedious and nearly every star system has 2 star gates to hack and it becomes old fast. The hacking puzzles differ by being timed and having to group specific colors in a specific order (yellow, than red, than blue, than yellow again, etc). It is extremely frustrating because what color pieces are moved onto the board everytime you clear any is random and there are times where you spend 15 seconds just grouping random colors to get the ones you need to show up. You can group clocks to get 10 additional seconds but adding a few more seconds doesn't make these any more enjoyable.  The other two types are mining and crafting. Its the same group three. You 'mine' for materials by grouping three or more until you have no moves left. No complaints but you don't get to choose what you keep if you mine too much. It'll even what you mine and you'll have to sell to make room. You can use those minerials to 'craft' which is another group three puzzle.  After a little over three hours and about 30 puzzles, I wasn't having fun. Game also crashed four times during those two hours.

i have always gotten a certain sick enjoyment from puzzle quest games until i played this. i gave it a chance, i even told myself it was a decent sleep aid. but holy ♥♥♥♥ i think it just bored me awake.

I really wanted to like this game, I really do. However, there's no probability because it's so random to where the 'gems' gravitate to. A little indicator would help a lot so the players can develop some kind of strategy. It's practically rigged for the AI conponent to win. The hexagonal shape match'em up was interesting concept but it's ruined due to the fact that your chances of winning deals with luck. Ignore this game and look elsewhere.

many of the reviews ponder if the game is cheating, and i can tell you it is. the computer is constantly getting chains, its almost as if it knows what gems are coming. at 1 point i had to fight a huge ship that had a ability that drains your red energy, thats your attack energy, you need it to use your lasers. the only way i could fight thriugh it was taking all the red gem combos before he could, but everytime i did it would set him up to bomb the crap out of me. after i won that battle and it took many times before the computer felt sorry for me and let me win, they say that was a hard battle in the cut scene. so basicaly your meant to loose over and over until it decides to let you continue the quest chain.   its a problem i see in every type of game with a computer ai, it knows what your doing the moment you make the montion. thats not loosing because your not good enough, its loosing because your set up to loose anyway. it works in something like computer chess, the computer knows all strats, so it knows all possible angles of attack. but you can still trick it, and you can also learn the same strats. but in alot of the computer ai games today like fighting games, your at the mercy of a computer ai. not only does it decide what gems are falling, but it also makes major difficultie bumps at any time, and in most games like PQ here, it will, alot, and then suddenly decide, ok you can win now. when it does that its not even a challenge then, like someone who has given up.  i was starting to get into it at first, made me think of mass effect but with puzzles. but once it was painfully clear i was playing a game with a all powerful AI god who controlled every thing like a vengeful god. i eventualy had to stop playing, cause every time i tried to appease the AI god, it would smack me down then forgive me.

Props to Puzzle Quest for trying a new take on the format, but in the end it's not worth it. Some of the mini-games (for example, mining) are fun, and it's enjoyable to play it as a little space economy simulator, flying around systems to find the place that will pay the most for isotopes or technology or what have you. Unfortunately the combat, which is essential to advance the plot, is much worse than in either of the 2 'traditional' puzzle quest games. Both sides have shields which are recharged by matching blue hexes, and the hit points are higher so it becomes much more of a slog to do a significant amount of damage. Except, of course, that once you cascade 4 or 5 chains in a row you go 'nova' and then 'supernova', which doubles the value of matches, which means that lucking into a cascade like this can do 50 or 60 points of damage (about 4 hours into the game I was doing fights where both sides had around 90 hp and around 30 shields, and standard attacks were doing around 7 or 9). Combat then becomes a matter of trying to match shields and hold out long enough that you can luck in to crazy high damage cascades before the computer does. There are items that will let you do various other things in battle, but they're scattered around the systems which makes it a pain to try to find an upgraded laser or whatever. Just play puzzle quest 1 or 2 if you really need to scratch that match-3 itch.
